body.p:
At the end of this month, I shall be, like you, an
ungowned parson, and therefore, I devote myself, before that time
to the pleasing duty of writing you a few lines, while I can still,
without opposition, claim the title of Revd. You are, no doubt, aware
that applications have, until very recently, been made to me by parties
in Savannah and Mobile, which were declined. Mr. Eckmann did
not please the folks here; indeed I don't know who can. The are very
willing to employ the best minister possible, but the truth is, they don't
want to pay. They would like Mr. Touro to do that duty. It is quite
honor sufficient that they have accepted his gift, and having secured
that effectually, their obligations are ended. They have been playing
a farce with me during the last fortnight. It ended as I foresaw,
with a positive rejection of their overtures. When they made their
proposals, they were, and are still, indebted to me for several months
services; which there is no likelihood of getting paid, unless out
of the old gentleman's pocket. He is heartily tired of these continued
draws on his purse, and I will no longer submit to be the a pensioner
on his bounty, when those who are able to satisfy my claims, lack
the will and inclination. Since my engagement in Feby 50, he
has paid nearly two thirds of my salary. Last May a great effort
was made, and a list was subscribed by several, by which offerings were to be abolished tacitly, and a contribution, to cover and include
seat rents and monthly dues, substituted. Many of the subscribers, in
good circumstances too, have broken faith; and those who have kept it,
now decline to keep to their engagement, because, they justly allege,

that the burthen of maintaining the synagogue ought not to
devolve on them alone. What the upshot is to be, time only will
reveal. But I can assure you, that however ardent my zeal to
devote myself to Israel's cause, I should be a fool to remain
here with the prospect of hard labor and no bread to eat. It is
certainly harsh to characterize the greater part of the congregation
as devoid of honor, principle, religion, and gratitude but it is
nevertheless perfectly true. I can prove it to be so to you and any
one's satisfaction. Mr. Touro has expressed himself satisfied
with my action and conduct; not so with those of the congregation.
Neither the decency and decorum of public worship, nor the advocacy
and exposition of our faith, have suffered thro' me in this city.
The synagogue has not lost a jot of its prestige from the night
of the consecration until this moment. This my congregation are
forced to admit, and, from the documents I send you, which you
are at liberty to publish in the Occident, if you think fit, they
are not willing to part with me. My object in forwarding them, is
to prove, if necessary, to the Jewish public, under what circumstances
I have taken leave of the ministry, and with what feelings. That
you may understand the whole proceedings, I must confide to you,
under the seal of secrecy, particulars, which you are not at liberty
to divulge, except with my consent. In February 51, finding that
there was no desire on the part of the Congregation to pay me my
salary, them 3 months in arrear, and Mr. Touro having until then
discharged the greater portion, I wrote to him, stating my painful
position, urging him either to endow the ministry, or to guarantee
the future payment of my stipend. The former he positively
declined, the latter he consented to, for 2 years, but no longer.
This guarantee expires with this month, and he will not renew

body.p:
it. The congregation knows nothing of this arrangement, but I com-
municate it to you, under the solemn request, that you will not
name it to any one, for the purpose of explaining my real motives
of retiring. Duty does not call on me to starve; and the congregation
with their magnificent offer of $2000 a year, can, but will never
pay me. I have no wish to be prejudiced by my people, nor yet
of exposing my constituents; yet, unless I admit you behind the
scenes, you will, I am certain, make some comments to my
disadvantage. Having revealed the above, you will acquit me
of any impropriety in sending in my letter of resignation in
July last. It was unconditional, because I could not maintain
myself here on less salary, and it enabled the congregation to engage
another person at a lower figure. They saw this at a glance, and
were glad that I cancelled a contract which tied me to them for
life. Hence they made no effort to induce me to recal my
resignation, but proceeded to act on it at once. Application was
made to you, and on your declining, to Mr. Echman. On his
accepting the situation at Mobile, Resolution No1 was passed at a General meeting.
I received the committee most kindly, but declined to reengage
myself until I was assured by a requisition, signed by a large
majority of the congregation, that they were favourable to my
reappointment. The committee admitted the justice of my
resolve, reported it at the next General Meeting, but when one of
them moved the appointment of a new committee to wait upon each
individual member of the congregation, and ascertain the general
feeling towards me, the motion was voted down by a large majority
out of 20 members present, and the Resolution No 2 in the second
committees letter was substituted. Do not lose sight of the fact, that
when they passed this Resolution, they owed me over 4 months salary;

body.p:
which is not yet liquidated, altho' there is a large amount
of arrearages due by persons in prosperous circumstances. My
letter in reply is No 3; and you must concede that it is a most
temperate and dignified one, considering the manner in with which
they treated my proposal. I stated to Mr. Touro, that if he
desired to retain me and engage my services I would remain; but that experience of 3 years had shown me that no dependence
was to be placed in the good faith and honor of the congregation;
and now, no circumstances, not even a requisition signed by
every one of them, will induce me to forego my determination
of leaving. I return to Jamaica in end this month, thence to Europe
where I propose taking up my abode in future.

And now, my dear Leeser, as we may possibly not
see each other again on earth, accept my most friendly and heartfelt
wishes for your happiness and success. In whatever part of the world my future lot will may be cast, I shall be delighted to hear from you
and rejoice to learn that you are more happy in the decline of life
than you have been in the meridian. Your name will be esteemed
and honored, and your worth acknowledged long after the grass has
grown over your grave, whilst your detractors will be forgotten as
tho' they had never been. My dear wife as usual sends her love,
and we both request you to tender our regards to our old
Philadelphia friends. That this may meet you in health and good spirits is the farewell greeting of

P.S. I will hand to G. Kursheedt before my
departure $9 for 3 yr subscription to the
Occident up to May 1853.
